issues.text: That ss. 8 and 10 of the Act should be so read that interest on securities, in cases where the true nature and character of the securities in the hands of an assessee is one of trading assets, would be excluded from the scope of s. 8 and would fall under the head business within s. 10 of the Act and alternatively even if ss. 8 and 10 are read as specific heads then s. 10, being more appropriate, should be applied to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellant has raised three points That ss. 8 and 10 of the Act should be so read that interest on securities, in cases where the true nature and character of the securities in the hands of an assessee is one of trading assets, would be excluded from the scope of s. 8 and would fall under the head business within s. 10 of the Act and alternatively even if ss. 8 and 10 are read as specific heads then s. 10, being more appropriate, should be applied to the facts of the present case

issues.text: If ss. 8 and 10 are equally applicable the assessee has the option to be taxed under that head which imposes a lighter burden on him.

anchor.surface_text: If ss. 8 and 10 are equally applicable the assessee has the option to be taxed under that head which imposes a lighter burden on him

issues.text: Even if the heads of income were to be taken as mutually exclusive so that the interest on securities falls under s. 8 and business under s. 10 of the Act, the assessee would be entitled to a set-off under s. 24(2) because interest on securities and profits and gains from business result from different operations of the same business.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly he contended that even if the heads of income were to be taken as mutually exclusive so that the interest on securities falls under s. 8 and business under s. 10 of the Act, the assessee would be entitled to a set-off under s. 24 (2) because interest on securities and profits and gains from business result from different operations of the same business, the two being different forms of the same business of the assessee.

holdings.text: Heads of income under sections 6 to 12 of the Income Tax Act are mutually exclusive; each item of income falls under one specific head and is computed under the corresponding section.

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised by counsel for the Revenue is that according to the decision of the Privy Council in Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor  s. 6 is the charging section and that the words of ss. 7 to 12 show that the various heads of income are mutually exclusive and items which specifically fall under these various heads have to be charged under only that head and would fall under one of these several but appropriately specific sections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Act under ss.3,4,6; language of ss.7-12 uses 'the tax shall be payable under the head'; supported by precedents like Probhat Chandra Barua, Salisbury House, and textual analysis showing classification by source.

holdings.text: Interest on securities is chargeable exclusively under section 8, even if securities are held as trading assets by a bank, and not under section 10 as business income.

anchor.surface_text: Thus on a true construction of the various sections of the Act the income of an assessee is one and the various ss. 7 to 12 are modes in which the Statute directs that income-tax is to be levied and these sections are mutually exclusive. The head of income of which the source is interest on securities has its characteristics for income-tax purposes and falls under the specific head covered by s. 8 of the Act, and where an item falls specifically under one head it has to be charged under that head and not another.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mutual exclusivity of heads; s.8 specifically covers interest on securities regardless of purpose; supported by return form under s.22(1), s.18 deduction at source, 1955 amendment to s.8 proviso, and precedents like Kothari, Salisbury House, Butler.

holdings.text: No option for assessee or Revenue to choose between heads if income falls specifically under one head like s.8 for interest on securities.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter no question of exercise of option by the assessee or the Revenue arises. Consequently Lord Shaw's observation in The Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance v. Bennett will be inapplicable to the facts of the present case, and so also the rule as to choosing the head which imposes on the assessee's shoulders burden which is lighter as given in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Bros., supra and reiterated in H. C. Kothari v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras supra.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Heads mutually exclusive, no overlap; rejects Bosotto Bros. option as inapplicable when specific head applies.

holdings.text: Question of set-off of carried forward business loss against interest on securities under s.24(2) not decided due to absence of Tribunal finding on whether holding securities forms part of assessee's same banking business.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the order we propose to make, we do not find it necessary to express any opinion on the respective contentions raised by counsel for the parties. In Punjab Co-operative Bank's case supra a finding had been given that the purchase and sale of securities was as much the assessee's business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them. In the case before us no such finding has been given and in the absence of such finding no opinion can be given as to whether the holding of securities out of which interest was derived formed part of the same business within s. 24 (2) or not.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: requires factual finding by Tribunal on 'same business'; distinguishes Punjab Co-op Bank where finding existed; question framed broadly covers point.

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised by counsel for the Revenue is that according to the decision of the Privy Council in Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor  s. 6 is the charging section and that the words of ss. 7 to 12 show that the various heads of income are mutually exclusive and items which specifically fall under these various heads have to be charged under only that head and would fall under one of these several but appropriately specific sections.

anchor.surface_text: Thus on a true construction of the various sections of the Act the income of an assessee is one and the various ss. 7 to 12 are modes in which the Statute directs that income-tax is to be levied and these sections are mutually exclusive. The head of income of which the source is interest on securities has its characteristics for income-tax purposes and falls under the specific head covered by s. 8 of the Act, and where an item falls specifically under one head it has to be charged under that head and not another.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the order we propose to make, we do not find it necessary to express any opinion on the respective contentions raised by counsel for the parties. In Punjab Co-operative Bank's case supra a finding had been given that the purchase and sale of securities was as much the assessee's business as receiving deposits from clients and withdrawals by them. In the case before us no such finding has been given and in the absence of such finding no opinion can be given as to whether the holding of securities out of which interest was derived formed part of the same business within s. 24 (2) or not.
